description.narrative: Insatsen utgör kärnstöd till Transparency International Zambias strategiska plan för perioden 2018 – 2022. Syftet/insatsens fokus är att bekämpa korruption i Zambia genom att på olika sätt stärka medborgares möjligheter till ansvarsutkrävande och transparens, samt att på olika sätt bidra till god samhällsstyrning.

The intervention constitutes core support to the Transparency International Zambia's strategic plan for the period 2018 to 2022. The focus of the intervention is to contribute to reducing corruption and promoting good governance in Zambia. The main objectives include empowering citizens to demand and take action against corruption; increasing awareness and capacity among citizens to demand accountability and transparency for the delivery of services; and enhancing the legal and policy environment as well as structures and enforcement mechanisms to promote good governance.
To contribute to the reduction of corruption and promotion of good governance in Zambia.

description.narrative: Transparency International Zambia (TI-Z) has continued to be active in its good governance and anti-corruption efforts. Broadly this has included building and strengthening integrity systems in public institutions; contributing to legal, policy and institutional reforms; contributing to public resource management and accountability; generating corruption evidence through research; people engagement; and anti-corruption information provision and outreach. Some specific examples of results within two programme areas are noted below: People Engagement & Advocacy (PEA) - The number of complaints and concerns about corruption and maladministration, received through TI-Z's Advocacy and Legal Advice Centre (ALAC) increased from 15 in 2018 to 50 in 2019. Of these 14 were clearly corruption related. From the 50 complaints received, 10 were active in court, 8 had been closed (due to insufficient evidence), 6 were presented before the Legal committee, out of which 2 had been referred to the Anti-Corruption Commission (ACC), 3 were undergoing administrative action from which 1 had resulted in legal action against the institution complained about. 6 had been referred to other Law Enforcement Agencies (LEAs) while 4 were miscellaneous and needed no analysis due to their nature. 8 concerned other institutions which were written to. 5 were yet to be analysed and presented before the committee. - TI-Z made progress in collaborating with service providers in promoting citizen participation in improved public service delivery across 6 districts (Chinsali, Chongwe, Kabwe, Kapiri Mposhi, Mongu and Livingstone). 20 Government departments were engaged and approximately 3,500 community members reached through engagement and community interface meetings respectively. Key outcomes from these meetings include; community interest to participate in improving public service delivery, service providers buy-in, collective identification of service delivery challenges, consensus on how to collectively deal with the identified service delivery challenges, and development of public service improvement plans. For instance, in Kapiri Mposhi, Chinsali, Chongwe, Mongu and Livingstone, service providers and target communities have collectively developed service improvement plans, which will be the basis for signing of integrity pacts (IPs) and a tool for both parties to monitor progress on the commitments in the IPs. Three out of five service providers responded to the issues presented to them Democratic Governance - In collaboration with the Judiciary, TI-Z developed 6,000 service charters for three courts namely; Subordinate, High and Small Claims Courts as integrity tools aimed at providing information to the general public on the operations and procedures of these Courts and disseminated in 18 districts- TI-Z Facilitated the review and reprinting of 10,000 Zambia Police Service Code of Ethics, as tools for promoting integrity and distributed in three provinces as well as distributing these through the Integrity Committee Focal persons on the Copper-belt, Central and Eastern Provinces. TI-Z provided further support to the Zambia Police by training 120 integrity committee focal point persons.
